body:
Each node as a Location structure that has first and last index. This linear index can then be remapped into a filename+line+column using the LocationManager.

Depending on what you are trying to do, we could save the AST + location into some kind of a JSON so that it's easy to import into, say, Python.

> Depending on what you are trying to do, we could save the AST + location into some kind of a JSON so that it's easy to import into, say, Python.

Yes that would be exactly what I'm looking for! Is this something you plan on implementing anyways? I could have a look at it myself, but given my limited time for such projects, limited C++ experience and total lack of compiler dev experience I suspect it would take ages to get anything done ðŸ¤”
I can implement it for you. But you then need to find time to at least try it. :)
Wow, thanks! I'll for sure find time for testing!

I would love to have this as well! (Will find time to test.)

I want to write a script will check all my files and print out all the locations where I forgot to use double precision for inline values 
(i.e. `a = b / 2.0` or worse `a = b / 2` instead of `a = b / 2d0`).
Not sure how this works in other compilers, but it causes a loss of precision in ifort on Windows and I literally spend days for every project finding these.

If I could get a JSON where I could look at the precision for each value and have the location in the source file, that would be just terrific!

Sorry I forgot to update this issue. We already implemented JSON printing:

* https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/1071
* https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/1078

It prints location information, but as a linear index. We still need to either save the line/column/file, or give you information how to do this yourself. @michaelkonecny or @plevold maybe you can implement this for us.

@michaelkonecny your idea should be a regular LFortran warning (configurable via a compile time option). But you can play with the JSON and give us feedback. I think you need ASR for this, not AST, since you need to know the types.

Ifort has the `-fpconstant` flag, but it doesn't cover all cases.
For example, in
```
real(8) :: a
a = 1.0/3.0
```
the value stored to `a` is still only calculated with single precision even with `-fpconstant` on.
The above is a good example of what I want to discover automatically with a script - it happens a lot (we often rewrite Matlab code to Fortran, one starts by copy pasting and it's easy to miss `1e7` in place of `1d7`).

Can you give me a hint on how to convert the linear index to file/line/column?
I would be up to implementing this.

Thanks

You could use function: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/blob/d2f947eed49002391830291420be48bcb74c767b/src/libasr/codegen/asr_to_llvm.cpp#L375, although I don't like how it is implemented there, it should accept the LocationManager as an argument, and not read the file at all (@Thirumalai-Shaktivel, we should fix that).  The other place where this is done is when printing error messages here: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/blob/d2f947eed49002391830291420be48bcb74c767b/src/libasr/diagnostics.cpp#L121, just call `LocationManager::pos_to_linecol`.
OK, I will look into that!

Do we want the line/column information only in the JSON or potentially everywhere?
If only in JSON, I can keep add a pointer to LocationManager in JsonBaseVisitor and initialize it in its constructor.
If everywhere, I would pass LocationManager to all the visitors and their visit functions, which is a bit more work and makes things a bit less readable.
Personally, I would prefer the first option.

Let's start with just JSON, with some minimal clean approach and then let's iterate.

I would recommend storing just the linear (integer first/last) location information and then store the information from the LocationManager only once in the header. Otherwise you have to store line, column and file (number) for each node, which I think will get quite verbose. Typically one would store a list of files first anyway, and then reference them with an index. So we might as well just use the linear index, and store filenames, line ends, etc. in the "header", and then we can provide simple Python functions to convert linear index into line+column+filename.

Yes, these lifetimes are the usual problem with C++. There is no good solution, one can use shared pointer, but then one has to initialize LocationManager using it as well. All things considered, I just pass it in via a constructor like you did. I typically use `&` and initialize it via the constructor initializer.

If you are going to go with storing just the linear index, you don't need to store the location manager in the class at all.

Regarding the remapping, it's not complicated, but it's not completely trivial either, you have to remap via the intervals (as the source code changes), and you have to do it twice, once for a C preprocessor, once for prescanning. We can put it into some examples and test it by the CI. Then people can just take it and use in their Python projects.

> Regarding the remapping, it's not complicated, but it's not completely trivial either, you have to remap via the intervals (as the source code changes), and you have to do it twice, once for a C preprocessor, once for prescanning. We can put it into some examples and test it by the CI. Then people can just take it and use in their Python projects.

I see. I thought it was simpler. If this is the case then I have two questions and a point:
1) is the added verbosity really a problem? (personally I could probably live with it)
2) if it is, can't we do something simpler, like just add line+col+fileID and then have a list of files and their IDs at the end (as the filename is susceptible be the most verbose part)?
3) if the overall output size is the issue, maybe we could start by minifying the JSON, this would more than counteract the added verbosity.

If possible, I think it would be a good idea to make the JSON as self-explanatory as possible. Having to use an extra script to decode the location means people will be less likely to use it, IMO.

Yes, we can do any of that. I think it depends on the application which option would be the best. I agree it's not ideal to use an extra script to decode. One issue that I will point out is that if you decode ahead of time, you lose the ability to track include files and macro expansions, you will just get the filename + line/column of the final destination, but it can be a different file. 

To make some progress, why don't you do the remapping and save line/column/filename (either a string or an id), and that would be a good start. Then we can iterate upon this later if needed.

About the LocationManager pointer in JsonBaseVisitor:
I've tried thinking about it from left and right and I can't think of a better solution. I looked more into passing a LM reference to all the visit functions, but that would mean having to create LocationManager in a lot of places where it's just not needed.

Here's a PR: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/1142 with the implementation with the pointer.
For now I kept the previous linear location as well. Should it be removed?

I also found out `test_ast_to_json` is probably failing now, so I guess that should be fixed. It also doesn't seem to be connected to CI.
Could you provide any pointers on how to build/run the test and do we want to connect it to CI?

Thanks.

Yes, I think we do not test the JSON output yet. We should.

Probably the easiest way is to hook it up into `./run_tests.py`, just like AST "lisp" like output.

I see. OK, that seems straight-forward.

In that case `test_ast_to_json.cpp` will still have no use. Shouldn't it be deleted?
I didn't figure out how this test was supposed to be run, perhaps someone can enlighten me (I figure it's an option I need to pass to cmake or make, but I'm not sure how to find out which one and I'm a bit lazy...).
On a related note, I added a mention of the `--json` option to the documentation here: #1143
I need to look into `test_ast_to_json.cpp`, it might be some old code that we can remove. I would worry about it later.

Just found out today that the JSON isn't valid on Windows because the filenames contain backslashes and they don't get escaped.
A quick fix would be simple - just escape the backslashes, but a better solution would probably be to use a library like [RapidJSON](https://rapidjson.org/) to generate the JSON.

This would also allow to generate a non-indented ("minified") version of the JSON in order to reduce the output size.
I guess this should happen when a switch like `--json-minify` is present.

What do you say?

The library is header-only, which is nice.
Does you guys use [vcpkg](https://github.com/Microsoft/vcpkg/) by any chance?
@certik I started implementing this using RapidJSON, so stop me now or never ;)
